title: WhatsApp users can now add music to their status
snippets: WhatsApp introduces a feature enabling users to add temporary music clips to their profile updates. This new function allows snippets from popular songs to be featured in WhatsApp statuses. The global rollout of this feature is underway and will continue to expand in the coming weeks, as announced by Meta, WhatsApp's parent company.
summary: WhatsApp has launched a new feature that lets users include short music clips in their profile updates. This update, which allows for snippets from popular songs to be added to WhatsApp statuses, is being released worldwide. Meta, the parent company of WhatsApp, has announced that the rollout will continue to expand in the coming weeks.

title: OpenAI has a Studio Ghibli problem
snippets: Recent internet trends show users creating a range of art using AI, from stylized family portraits to variations of the Distracted Boyfriend meme. This trend highlights the diverse creative potential of AI, producing both beautiful and unsettling artworks.
summary: Recent internet trends reveal users utilizing AI to create various artworks, including stylized family portraits and new versions of the Distracted Boyfriend meme. This showcases the wide-ranging creative capabilities of AI, generating art that is both appealing and disturbing.

title: Android Auto’s latest beta brings full Android game support
snippets: Google is introducing gaming support to Android Auto, allowing games like Candy Crush Soda Saga and Angry Birds 2 to be played on the touchscreens of compatible cars. This feature is part of the beta version of Android 14.1, currently available to testers. As of now, only four games are supported.
summary: Google has launched a beta version of Android 14.1, introducing gaming support to Android Auto. This new feature enables users to play games such as Candy Crush Soda Saga and Angry Birds 2 on the touchscreens of compatible vehicles. Currently, the gaming support includes only four games.

title: Our favorite robot vacuum deals from Amazon’s Big Spring Sale
snippets: In the current era, technology allows for the delegation of tasks to automated devices, such as self-driving cars and cleaning robots. While advanced sentient robots may not be affordable for most people in their lifetimes, robot vacuums offer a more accessible option for automated assistance in household chores.
summary: Technology today enables tasks to be automated with devices like self-driving cars and cleaning robots. Although highly advanced sentient robots may remain out of financial reach for many during their lifetimes, robot vacuums provide a more accessible form of automated help with household chores.

title: Amazon’s big spring sale continues, and we found the 95 best deals

The sale is timed to align with the start of spring and the flowering season.

title: A genetic tree as a movie: Moving beyond the still portrait of ancestry
snippets: Researchers have developed a statistical method that transforms the traditional family tree into a dynamic movie, illustrating the global movements of ancestors over time. This innovative approach not only enhances genealogical research but also has applications in tracking disease spread and analyzing animal migration patterns across different regions.
summary: Researchers have created a new statistical method that turns traditional family trees into dynamic movies, showing ancestors' global movements over time. This method improves genealogical research and can be used to track disease spread and study animal migration patterns.

title: Melting ice, more rain drive Southern Ocean cooling
snippets: Researchers have identified that 60% of the discrepancy between expected and actual ocean temperatures around Antarctica over several decades is due to increased meltwater and rainfall in the area.
summary: Researchers found that 60% of the difference between predicted and actual ocean temperatures near Antarctica is caused by higher amounts of meltwater and rainfall in the region over several decades.

title: Long COVID patients feel pressure to prove their illness is real, study finds

title: Cartilage and bone development: Three paths to skeleton formation
snippets: Researchers have found that in vertebrates, the skeleton's various parts are formed from distinct precursor cells, each with unique gene regulation. This variation in gene regulation among skeletal cells from different body regions could play a crucial role in vertebrates' evolutionary success.
summary: Researchers discovered that vertebrate skeletons are made from different precursor cells, each with unique gene regulation. This diversity in gene regulation among skeletal cells from various body parts may have significantly contributed to the evolutionary success of vertebrates.

title: Terahertz imaging: Breakthrough in non-invasive cochlear visualization
snippets: Researchers have developed a non-invasive, high-resolution THz imaging technique to visualize cochlear structures in mice, enabling 3D reconstructions. This advancement could revolutionize diagnostics for hearing loss and other conditions by potentially leading to the creation of miniaturized THz diagnostic devices, improving diagnostic speed, accuracy, and patient outcomes.
summary: Researchers have created a non-invasive, high-resolution imaging method using terahertz (THz) technology to visualize the cochlear structures in mice, allowing for 3D reconstructions. This breakthrough could lead to the development of compact THz diagnostic tools, enhancing the speed and accuracy of diagnosing hearing loss and other conditions, and potentially improving patient outcomes.

title: We must not ignore eugenics in our genetics curriculum, says professor

summary: Mark Peifer, a biology professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, recommends incorporating eugenics into college genetics curriculums. He argues that this will encourage scientists to confront the misuse of science for political aims.
